A different privacy policy and terms of service will apply. 941-366-1552 About Us: The Jazz Club of Sarasota is the most active jazz club in the United Sates, with over 80 concerts and lectures each year. Founded in 1980 by the late Hal Davis, the former publicist for Benny Goodman, the club has approximately 750 members and is growing in membership. The club sponsors, with the Van Wezel Performing Arts Hall, the Sarasota Jazz Festival, one of the major US jazz festivals. The club also sponsors the Venice Jazz Festival in Venice Florida and the Gulf Coast High School Jazz Festival in Sarasota. Contact / “ The mission is clear, the communication is exceptional, and the willingness of staff and educators to find solutions and opportunities where others see problems is meaningfully apparent. ” — JazzED Parent Seattle JazzED Staff BJ Montoya, Curriculum Manager and Lead Teacher BJ’s passion for teaching music must have come from a family history of teachers and musicians. His grandparents were school teachers in the Philippines. And as they immigrated to North America, they were sure to bring and share their musical traditions as instrumentalists and dancers. His musical journey started as a student of Suzuki Violin Method for over 13 years at the University of Louisville School of Music Prep School. He also performed with the Louisville Youth Orchestra and other small local ensembles. Beyond the classical foundation, the violin has afforded him an opportunity to express a wider range of styles.  Since arriving in Seattle in 2001, he has been performing in a range of venues from sanctuaries to coffee shops to night clubs. He has been featured in local indie bands, gospel choirs, theater productions and his longstanding Irish party band, Whiskey Mary. His teaching builds from these experiences emphasizing social playing and creative expression through the many dialects that music has to offer whether fiddle, classical or jazz. BJ looks forward to sharing his passion for music and the joy the wonderfully versatile instrument can offer. Tessa Pargiter-Hatem, Operations Director Tessa Pargiter-Hatem first worked with Seattle JazzED as the event coordinator for the annual fundraising gala, and is thrilled to be transitioning into a more prominent operations and events position. As a graduate of the University of Washington, she is eager to be returning to Seattle’s expansive music community and deepening her PNW roots. Tessa brings a diverse skill set to her work at Seattle JazzED, with experience in environmental nonprofits, film, and the food and beverage industry. As an enthusiastic life-long learner, Tessa is motivated to help students and their families express themselves and build community through music education. When she’s not in the office, you’ll find her cycling up mountains or skiing down them, listening to anything from Pink Martini to Fred Again. Liz Riggs Meder, Executive Director Liz is an educator and nonprofit leader with a background in guiding organizations through growth and change to expand their reach and impact. She is passionate about creating access for diverse audiences and has done that for programs ranging from science curriculum for youth to outdoor risk management for adults. Profoundly shaped by her music education experience through her school years, she is eager to return to the music world and to use her change management skills to support making rich music education more accessible to all students. Liz is a long-time Seattle resident and can be found playing in the mountains either skiing down them or slowly running over them. Alyssa Seng, Communications Manager Alyssa Seng is a second-generation Southeast Asian American and a first-generation college graduate. Raised by refugees in a diverse Southern California town, her values and passion for equity and community-building are a product of the unique blend of cultures that surrounded her. She’s excited to leverage her background in communications, having worked on advocacy initiatives ranging from amplifying student voices to leading statewide public health campaigns, to support JazzED’s mission of increasing access to arts education. Raijene Walker, Development Director Raijene Walker brings over a decade of nonprofit leadership and a B.S. in Communication (specializing in Interpersonal and Organizational Communication) to Seattle JazzED. Her career spans impactful roles with youth-focused organizations including City Year, the Wade Edwards Foundation, and the Girl Scouts where she’s leveraged her communication expertise to cultivate meaningful partnerships, attract strategic support, and amplify fundraising efforts. Originally from Baltimore, Maryland, Raijene is excited to make Seattle her new home and be part of its vibrant, collaborative arts community. A lifelong lover of the arts, she looks forward to combining her passion for creativity, community, and development to support and advance JazzED’s mission of equitable arts education. Seattle JazzED Board of Directors Christian Anderson Private Wealth Advisor at Goldman Sachs Christian is a former Jazz Saxophonist turned Wealth Advisor based in Seattle. Having grown up in the Pacific Northwest as a beneficiary of the excellent public music education ecosystem, he is grateful for the opportunity to stay connected and give back through his involvement with Seattle JazzED. Christian graduated from NYU with a bachelor's degree in Jazz Saxophone and Economics. Robert Babs Development Operations Manager at Seattle Opera Former Seattle JazzED Program and Operations Manager, Robert is a life-long musician and dedicated arts administrator with a passion for youth arts and education. He has worn many hats through his years of nonprofit involvement as both staff and a volunteer, working almost exclusively in programs around the greater Seattle area which strive to provide youth and educators with quality and meaningful artistic experiences. A born and raised Seattle local, Robert studied English and History at the University of Washington, with minors in Music and French Studies. Though not a jazz musician himself, he’s a great jazz appreciator. Robert’s current musical activities are as a violist of the Puget Sound Symphony Orchestra (among others), a music coach-clinician in Seattle Public Schools, and playing chamber music with friends whenever possible. When not working, volunteering, or playing music Robert is an avid social dancer (contra, swing, and waltz). He also serves on the advisory board of Meany Center for the Performing Arts. Harold Brandford Physician / Anesthesiologist Harold moved to Seattle forty years ago to finish his medical training. Still working as an anesthesiologist but in the process of exploring opportunities to become more socially involved, five years ago he discovered Seattle JazzED. He welcomed an opportunity to join the board and has served as chair of the Gala Committee for the past two years. He is excited by the fact that JazzED has transformed the lives of thousands of youngsters in the area, and looks forward to the occupancy of our new home, JazzHouse. Jeff Clapsaddle Community Volunteer Bio coming soon. Katie Hughes Director, Environmental, Health & Safety and Sustainability (EHSS) - Global Corporate Offices at Amazon Katie Hughes oversees the health, safety, and sustainability of a global corporate portfolio. She spearheads implementing pioneering practices, like a global indoor air quality program, and received the Mary L. McClinton Patient Safety Award (2022) for her work delivering COVID-19 vaccines to over 145k community members. Katie is a firm believer in supporting the community. When she is not working, Katie enjoys spending time with her family and, when time permits, going golfing. Erica Garvey Finance and Real Estate Professional Erica has been a fan of jazz and jazz education starting from her days in high school jazz band. She got involved with JazzED after reading a news article about the new school the organization was planning to build, and quickly developed an interest in the whole program. Erica currently works in corporate finance for a Seattle-based tech company, and has spent much of her professional career in commercial real estate investment and development. She is an avid consumer of live music and you can often find her out in Seattle catching one of the many great local bands. Erica lives with her dog, Seven, and splits her time between Seattle and Colorado. Angie Jenkins Director of Seattle University Learning Assistance Programs Angie is originally from Kingston, Jamaica, and currently serves as the Director of Learning Assistance Programs at Seattle University, a program with the purpose of offering comprehensive academic support to students outside of the classroom to contribute to their overall success.  She has worked at Seattle University since 2005 and in the education field (pre-school through higher education) for over 20 years. Angie is an active member on various committees supporting her children's education experiences, particularly around equity, access and inclusion work.  This focus is what drew her to JazzEd years ago when her son participated in one of their summer programs.  She was struck by their commitment to issues of access and equity and genuine desire to serve the BIPOC community not just in statements but in daily practice.  This has continued to be evident as she has been on the board and she is excited to be a part of this journey. Erica McIntyre Staff Accountant at Seattle Opera Erica is a nonprofit accountant at Seattle Opera with a background in jazz saxophone. She is a graduate of Interlochen Arts Academy high school, and Seattle University where she got her degree in Finance with Accounting. Erica was introduced to JazzED after learning about their Femme Ellington Project, and is inspired by JazzED’s intentional programming to strengthen gender diversity in jazz music education (a cause that is extremely personal to her). Outside of work, Erica performs improv comedy, loves to read, and pushes listening to 1960’s Hard bop jazz albums onto all her friends. Shirish Mulherkar Community Volunteer Shirish Mulherkar co-founded Seattle JazzED in 2010 and served as the President of the Board of Trustees for the first four years. Shirish has a B.S. in Chemical Engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology and a M.S. in Urban and Policy Sciences from S.U.N.Y. at Stony Brook.  He has worked as a systems engineer at Brookhaven National Laboratory; the Mellon Institute; Applied Energy Services and Carhart Associates. He moved to Seattle in 1985 and worked in the financial services industry where he advised pension funds, mutual funds and money management firms. Shirish and his wife Anne have two adult children, Andrew and Riley. In his spare time, he enjoys travel, art, tennis, and playing the guitar. Shirish is committed to JazzED because he believes that access to arts and music is a critical element in every child's education and creates a healthier culture and society. Chris Nelson Director, Content | Arts & Culture at Pyramid Communications Chris the director of the Arts & Culture practice at Pyramid Communications, a firm that collaborates with nonprofits on strategy, communications, and creative projects. As the A&C lead, he has worked alongside KEXP, Pearl Jam in their Home Shows initiative, MoPOP, the Julia Keefe Indigenous Big Band, Seattle JazzED, and numerous others folks. Chris was formerly a music journalist, both on staff at MTV, and freelancing for the New York Times, Rolling Stone, MOJO, and others. Whether he’s working with arts clients or those in other areas (such as education, climate, or Indian Country), Chris typically focus on editorial work, such as messaging, as well as on media outreach. One of Chris and his family’s favorite things to do together is see live music. Caroline Perkins Retired Educator Caroline comes to Seattle JazzED following more than 25 years in public and adult education. She earned her degrees from UC Berkeley and San Francisco State and began her career teaching low income and ESL students. Following her career in elementary education, Caroline was active with the music programs at Washington Middle School and Garfield High School. Caroline has a keen respect for the importance of stability, personal connection, and access to resources and life experiences, for individual development and future success. Her sons benefited greatly from access to excellent music education and she wants the same for any student regardless of background, or ability to pay. For Caroline, JazzED checks all the boxes. Caroline is a connector and loves being active and involved. She splits her time between Seattle and her family farm in Sacramento River Delta of California. In addition to serving on the board for Seattle JazzED, Caroline is a member of the California River Council. Kyle Rolfe Vice President, Wright Hotels Inc. Kyle was born in Seattle and has local roots going back five generations. He has worked in the construction and real estate development industry over the last 15 years managing commercial
projects for Amazon & Facebook and civic projects for MOHAI and the
Space Needle. Kyle & his wife reside in Phinney Ridge where they are raising three young children, the oldest of which just started drum lessons. Kyle got involved in JazzED during the development of JazzHouse as a consultant and fundraiser on the Campaign Advancement Team. He is passionate about community building and mission-based real estate development. Kyle is also on the board of a grantmaking foundation where he leads a committee devoted to community lead, trust-based resourcing. For fun Kyle enjoys the great outdoors, cooking, soccer, and travel. Debra Smiley Senior Trust Analyst, Laird Norton Wealth Management Debra joined Laird Norton Wealth Management in 2017 and is a senior trust analyst. In her current role, Debra collaborates with LNWM’s client service teams to help them administer trusts established by clients. With more than 15 years of experience in trust administration, Debra truly enjoys helping people build a lasting legacy for the next generation. Kacie Washington HR and Operations/Consulting at Stepherson & Associates Kacie has over 15 years of experience developing and leading brand initiatives. She is a strategic storyteller with a background in content creation, project management, and community engagement. She’s worked with startups, local and national non-profits, and global brands. When she’s not writing, you can find her cooking with her children or hosting a party for friends and family. Kacie is a champion of turning dreams into reality. Founded in 1980 by the late Hal Davis, the former publicist for Benny Goodman, the Jazz Club has approximately 1,000 members and is growing. The Club has provided over 70 jazz-related events annually for more than 40 years. Chief among them is the highly respected weeklong Sarasota Jazz Festival, which presents some of the greatest musicians on today’s jazz scene in an eclectic mix of events. Other ongoing Jazz Club programs include Friday’s Jazz at Two concerts from October through April, Jazz on the Water cruises and the Monday Night Jazz series. The Jazz Club also promotes high school jazz bands and has granted nearly one-quarter million dollars in scholarships to aspiring young jazz musicians over the years. Join us to share in the excitement of live jazz performances by masterful established musicians and talented rising stars! Create a pro account The association Paris Jazz Club PARIS JAZZ CLUB, The Network of Jazz Venues is a non-profit organization created in 2006 to promote, celebrate and democratize jazz in all its forms, especially through jazz venues. Paris Jazz Club is thus conducting a real groundwork to promote Paris as the second largest jazz capital after New York, and consequently its French region and the whole French territory. Drawing on a network of more than 130 member venues and festivals throughout the year, Paris Jazz Club carries out various activities to make as many people as possible discover the diversity and richness of jazz, but also represent the dynamism of French jazz creation internationally. Discover all our actions The festival Jazz sur Seine is a must in October. For his 14th edition from the 10th to 25th of October, it will be more festive and ambitious than ever ! Created by Paris Jazz Club, the network of jazz venues, festival purpose this year 200 concerts, involving 450 musicians in 25 venues between Paris and its region Jazz on Seine The Paris and its region Jazz Clubs host their festival ! French Quarter, Jazz in NYC is a innovative device of showcases destined to argue the energy of the new french jazz scene close to professionals of the whole world present at New York on occasion of the APAP and Winter Jazz Festival. French Quarter The best of french jazz in America! Led by artists like Avishai Cohen, Yaron Herman, Omer Avital, Israel has become one of the great scenes of international jazz . After New York and Paris, Tel-Aviv is now the 3rd jazz capital in the world, as the musicians' pool is abundant, facilitated by a remarkable network of music schools. Integrating so subtly Arab harmonies inherited from traditional music to jazz, the Israeli scene is open to the world and probably carries more than a musical color: a symbol of peace through music. Paris Jazz Club nights Israeli Jazz Focus 10 issues per year 30 000 copies provided free of charge per month 500 delivery points 600 announced jazz concerts per month 450 000 annual readers 1 electronic release downloadable on ou website Paris Jazz Club Agenda The only free & monthly jazz schedule in Paris and its surrounding area. Proclaimed in November 2011 by UNESCO, the International Jazz Day is held each April, the 30th in a hundred countries in 5 continents, to promote jazz as part of universal dialogue and a factor of peace between people. In Paris, the Association is the official organizer since 2013. Concerts, showcases, masterclasses and workshops are held for free to 2000 people each year. In 2015, Paris Jazz Club was requested to manage jazz events all over the city on the occasion of the great Jazz evening at the UNESCO headquarters in Paris. International Jazz Day in Paris Thanks to the success of the jazz discovery worshops organized during Jazz sur Seine Festival since 2013, Paris Jazz Club won a public contract of the City Hall of Paris to roll out jazz dicovery workshops in numerous primary schools all over the year. Youngs Parisians are sensitized to jazz thus through musical listening, jazz history, instrumental and vocal practice around some revisited jazz standards, supervised by professional artists . Jazz discovery workshops for children For the young people of the "Réussite éducative d'Ile-de-France" during Jazz sur Seine festival & for the students of parisians primary schools Community Management pooling service Payroll and Social management pooling services Social and tax quarterly newsletter Representation of the network during national and international exhibitions, membership in local (réseau Map) and international networks (Europe Jazz Network) Federating partnerships on all or part of the network : Fête de la Musique, Pass Adami, Institut Français Seasons, Nuit Blanche, Paris Music... Jazz club privatizations for private events Network structuring & jazz venues support By pooling services, information and representing its jazz venues members, Paris Jazz Club participates extensively in the structuring of french jazz network This Membership Card is a real loyalty card to the jazz clubs. For 40€ / year, our 1000 active members have access to the most prestigious clubs with more than 70 free concerts / year and many discounts for jazz events (festivals, clubs, etc). More than 70 free concerts / year in our partner jazz clubs : Duc des Lombards, Baiser Salé, Sunset/Sunside, 38 Riv', Triton, le 360 Reduces prices for many clubs in Paris Special tarrifs for some festivals and partners events Special Offer for Work Councils available. Jazz Thursday at the Sarasota Art Museum Presented by Sarasota Art Museum and Jazz Club of Sarasota at Sarasota Art Museum , Sarasota FL Nov 14 2024 photo credit - Carol LoRicco Enjoy the sounds of the big band with the Sarasota Jazz Project. Join us for live jazz at Sarasota Art Museum, hosted by the Jazz Club of Sarasota, and extended hours in the galleries, Bistro, and SHOP! Sip on refreshing cocktails and enjoy small bites in the Bistro. Each second Thursday of the month features a different style of jazz–from straight-ahead to free jazz, bebop to swing–programmed in partnership with Jazz Club of Sarasota. On Thursday November 14, we feature big band jazz with the Sarasota Jazz Project. The SJP is one of the finest big bands on Florida’s Westcoast and they present music from the big band era with contemporary arrangements. Each second Thursday of the month features a different style of jazz–from straight-ahead to free jazz, bebop to swing–programmed in partnership with Jazz Club of Sarasota. On Thursday November 14, we feature big band jazz with the Sarasota Jazz Project. The SJP is one of the finest big bands on Florida’s Westcoast and they present music from the big band era with contemporary arrangements. Enjoy jazz standards and American Songbook with vocals by Katy Cristiani. Galleries are open until 7 pm on Jazz Thursdays. Concert begins 5:30 pm; Tickets: museum members and supporters free, limited number of free tickets for Jazz Club members, others admission $25. About Us | Sarasota Jazz Project Loading... Skip to main content The premier big band of Florida's gulf coast Contact: George McLain (941) 587-3621 Home About Gigs Musicians Gallery Contact About Us “Sarasota Jazz Project” is a high energy 17 piece jazz ensemble comprised of some of the finest musicians on the West Coast of Florida. These talented all-stars play both original compositions and standard tunes, creatively arranged in a unique contemporary Big Band style. Whether you dance, or listen or both, be prepared to be thoroughly entertained. The Sarasota Jazz Project Big Band performs at jazz concerts, clubs, schools/universities, private clubs, and Jazz Club of Sarasota events throughout the year. The Sarasota Jazz Project Big Band is dedicated to the preservation, promotion, and public performance of big band jazz music in Sarasota and the neighboring communities in the State of Florida.  Founded in February 2010 by George McLean and George McLain (no relation!), the band is comprised of the best available local musicians, including professional jazz musicians with long resumes and careers in performing with top-name bands and jazz musicicans throughout the world.  Members also include local music teachers and educators; working musicians who perform regularly in local theaters,orchestras and cabaret venues; and other serious local musicians who maintain "day jobs" and play jazz for the sheer pleasure and exhilaration of being a part of this true American art form. While respecting and performing music of great big bands of the past led by such luminaries as Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Stan Kenton and Glen Miller, the Sarasota Jazz Project emphasizes the work of modern composers and arrangers such as Miles Davis, Wayne Shorter, Quincy Jones, and Gil Evans.  Perhaps the most distinctive element of the Sarasota Jazz Project repetoire is its great collection of popular music and standards arranged in new and exciting jazz settings by the very best current musical arrangers in the world, including George Stone, Brad Morey, Gary Urwin, Ed Vizinho, Don Schamber, Gordon Goodwin and John Clayton. Our Goal The specific goal of the Sarasota Jazz Project is to expose the jazz-loving public to these new sounds and musical settings, including original compositions and arrangements written by our own members.  While the Band will perform some of the great treasure of existing literature at the highest level of artistry and taste, including respresetative vocal renditions of classics by Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett, Nat King Cole, and Mel Torme, the emphasis of Sarasota Jazz Project is the preservation and expansion of America's only true native musical art form through innovation in the performance of existing standard works and dedication to locating and presenting the best new works to the public. Jazz, like America itself, prospers through improvisation, innovation, exploration and growth.  The Sarasota Jazz Project is a vibrant part of that improvisation, innovation, exploration and growth.  Audiences can expect to hear a unique and eclectic blend of popular jazz standards, favorites from the "Great American Song Book" presented in current new arrangements and styles, as well as modern compositions being heard for the first time.  Whether performing in concert, clubs, cabarets, or country clubs, Sarasota Jazz Project provides music that is both listenable and danceable, both familiar and challenging.  But always expect to hear the spontaneous creativity that is the essence of Jazz! As funding becomes available, we hope to commission original works and compositions for premier performances here in the Sarasota area.  In short, the Sarasota Jazz Project will continue to make a significant contribution toward maintaining Sarasota as the "Cultural Capitol of Florida.” We have performed and recorded in the following cities: Sarasota Bradenton Tampa Sun City Center Port Charlotte We frequently collaborate with the Jazz Club of Sarasota for concerts and events.  We do private and public parties, so give us a call to jazz up your event today!
